commentBody: Underlines don‚Äôt show up in the app, so the theme makes no sense

Print is going away‚Ä¶they better get used to it.

No underlines on NYT iPad app. I‚Äôm tempted to use profanity.

I am on iOS. The underlines did not show up for me. This is like the third time in the last three months, NYT. Get your mobile development team together and figure it out. This is unacceptable (in a ‚Äúfirst world problem‚Äù kind of way).

ATTA, that palindromic whole-wheat flour from SOUTH Asia (i.e. the Indian subcontinent), has only recently been clued as such most of the time, as opposed to "___ boy!" or "___ girl!", which is what the primary clue was before 2020...unless you go WAY back, to the 70s, when it was periodically interspersed with the other clues.  It was also occasionally clued in the early days as the sweetsop, or a type of ant, and as Kofi Annan's middle name around when he was the UN Secretary General.

Interestingly, from its first appearance, ATTA was clued with "___ boy!" exactly 100 times (if my counting was accurate) before it was ever clued with "____ girl!"  I guess girls didn't achieve anything in the mid-20th century...

I‚Äôm using the Games app on my iPhone and also didn‚Äôt see the underlined letters. I finished the puzzle pretty quickly but had no clue what the theme was before reading Wordplay. 

Not only are the ongoing app issues frustrating as a solver, they‚Äôre frankly disrespectful to the constructors who put so much effort into the puzzles.
I really wish NYT would stop publishing puzzles that don‚Äôt work in all formats. It‚Äôs an insult to solvers. (Underlining did not show in the app).

I never knew that the Philly train system is called SEPTA. There's got to be a joke there somewhere.  Nice theme - I caught on fairly quickly that, even if I could not get the answer immediately, that there was an 'AND' in the middle, and that helped.

Quick-ish for a Thursday.
You have to let those of us using the app know we‚Äôre not getting the full clues. It‚Äôs hard not to feel cheated.
Good thing the theme answers were common phrases or else I would have struggled to solve this puzzle with the lack of underlines. Still got a Thursday PB too!

Guess I missed out on theme clues on digital, but not too hard to figure out what goes in from the crosses. Honestly, I thought it was a ‚Äúrelated common phrase‚Äù type puzzle or something. 

Incidentally, I finished in well under half my usual time for a Thursday. Either some sort of gas leak in my apartment suddenly stopped this week, or the NYT saved all its ‚Äúvery easy for the day they‚Äôre intended for‚Äù puzzles for the start of the year. Could be either! Hoping for a couple of tough ones to round out the week.
Deeply disappointing. I got the format quickly, and it was a speedy solve, but like others, I couldn‚Äôt see underlined letters solving digitally, and the clues didn‚Äôt make sense.

Also - yeah, sometimes the app doesn‚Äôt do something the way it was intended- but really - the level of upset‚Ä¶.  If you really missed that Thursday feeling- click on archive and choose from almost 1,500 other Thursdays.

The odds of getting two ones when rolling two dice are 35:1, not 36:1.

Formatting issues on the app have been quite common lately, and really take away from the user experience. The constructors put in so much effort to create fun and challenging puzzles, only for them to be let down by software issues. Is no one at NYT testing these before release? Very disappointing.

Well Gosh I don‚Äôt know what all the phone app users like myself are complaining about. The theme was simple, each answer is a synonym for the clue, the word ‚Äúand‚Äù and some other word that has nothing to do with the clue but finishes a common expression. How very clever!

Seriously though this could have been a simple fix why not capitalize some letters but not the rest? CarOL brAdy. Pretty obvious, but so would have been the underlines if we saw them. Either way kind of tame for a Thursday, and frankly a slap in the face to the creators. I‚Äôd be pretty disappointed putting all this work in a puzzle, getting it published, and having probably a majority of solvers not get to enjoy my theme.

It‚Äôs a shame that the brilliance of this puzzle will be marred for so many by the technical issue. I thoroughly enjoyed the solve. 

I also had fun trying to figure out what letters would be underlined in the additional examples. My guesses are 

BEAM, UP, GO, HOUR and NERD.

Thanks, Christina and Chase.
The underlined letters were there on my Samsung phone using the Android app.

Oh man.  I‚Äôm bummed. But relieved

I can‚Äôt imagine trying to ‚Äúsleep on it‚Äù to figure out the trick, only to see this was a ‚Äútechnical issue.‚Äù  Woulda been a lot more frustrated than I am now. 

But the ultimate troll job was having additional ones in the constructor notes and not underlining those!   Pretty sure, the column could handle underscoring.  

So sadly. Too easy for a Thursday. And not fun because of the glitch.  Regrettable for the constructors.  Just my opinion.

I‚Äôm glad I came to the column to figure out how the second part of the phrases made sense. I still ended up with a Thursday PR, so I‚Äôm not complaining.

Welllllll......

On my puzzle, nothing was underlined.

After filling out the entire puzzle, I looked at Wordplay to comprehend the uppercase clues.

So overall, rather confusing, but I get it now.

Another point: In today's Constructor Notes, the puzzle makers share five examples that didn't make it into the puzzle. I'm not the first to observe that nothing there was underlined. I see nada on my screen even without printing anything out. Are we supposed to guess what they are?

Do subscribers to the puzzles app get a refund?
Seriously‚Ä¶ unsolvable except by process of elimination 
Why can‚Äôt letters be underlined in the app? It makes no technological sense!

Deb-- out of curiosity why don't they put the technical note in the "i"? They could make it flash like how they do on Sunday's. Seems like a very easy fix that can be done at any time (even now...)

Incidentally I solved it without knowing there was an issue and that I just couldn't figure out the theme. Would have been so much more satisfying (and a quicker solve) to have gotten it.

Solved it but didn‚Äôt ‚Äúget it‚Äù on my iPad. Seems to me that blending upper and lower case letters would have achieved the appropriate effect in a better way and without leaving half of us in the dark.
Technical issues aside, I solved this in under 12 minutes without outlines so I'll refrain from complaining.

Deb, you allude to crossword solving as taking you to a happy place. I was feeling glum so I got out of bed to sit by the tree lights and solve the crossword ‚Äî a lovely habit of the past few weeks. I don‚Äôt mind not getting every theme but it is rather disappointing that there are so many simple solutions to the underline issue ‚Äî in addition to those already mentioned, why didn‚Äôt the editors just include some directions on the title page (which they have often done in the past) to read your column first? I know you are not responsible for the issue but I hope that the frustration many of us are feeling gets forwarded on to those who handle the tech side: like many have said, it seems a real shame for the constructors to go to all the trouble of creation just to have so many of their audience get left in the dark. Thanks for listening, Deb.

Off to bed‚Ä¶can‚Äôt imagine how many comments there will be when I wake tomorrow.

While engaged in a crossword, I often think about the constructors and all the effort they put into creating an interesting and entertaining diversion to my day.  

It makes me smile every time.  (Take that, cortisol!)

It does not matter if the clues push me, or if the theme eludes me, or if there is a technical difficulty such as an app issue.  I think about how constructors are passionate about their craft, and how they partake in a lengthy task that benefits me.

As far as I am concerned, the constructors always deserve to receive gratitude.

Thank you, Chase Dittrich and Christina Iverson, for a clever and creative crossword! 

Also, thank you to Deb Amlen and all the columnists for insights that deepen the experience.  Thank you to the editing team for guiding good crossword ideas to life.  And, thank you to the technical team who make the app experience possible.  

All of your efforts add a bit of extra joy to my life.

With 2.6 million daily users of the NYT Games app (per a Vanity Fair article citing data from mid-October 2023), and the NYT using Games as a centerpiece of its growth strategy, you‚Äôd think they could figure out formatting on the app‚Ä¶

What made it stellar for me was the amazing creativity of the constructors.
"How on earth do they come up with these brilliant ideas?" I kept asking myself.

That smile Deb got on her face... it's the same one on mine.

Grammatically distressed every time I'm reminded that 'wrack' is being inevitably replaced by 'rack.'

It's like the slow phasing out of the word 'whom,' from the language.  No one is doing it on purpose.  And to whom does one petition for its preservation?

Re: wrack: even a quick, cursory internet review of the etymology of the word would prove just how important that 'w' is, to the meaning.

There is no such thing as 'rack and ruin,' just like a ship is not 'recked' and one does not 'reak' havoc.

I'm no linguist, and it took me all of 7 seconds to find on Wikipedia:
"[rack and ruin]: Etymologically incorrect, due to confusion of rack (‚Äútorture, suffer‚Äù) with wrack (‚Äúdestroy‚Äù). Correct is wrack and ruin, which is accordingly preferred by style guides; however, both are common and well-established. Unusually, rack and ruin replaces wrack with rack, presumably by alliteration; other confusions instead replace rack with wrack"

The puzzle a couple months back with the musical notation that showed up as black boxes I (sort of) understood. But this? Underlining letters was too hard for the app? Sheesh.

We can get a puzzle with an animated Eve Knievel jumping over buses but we can‚Äôt get four letters underlined?
For the app, a simple solution would have been to substitute lowercase for underlines, e.g. cARol BRaDY

I feel so bad for Christina and Chase. Would have been a lovely Thursday, if not for the unforgivable lack of testing. 

Given the long lead times before submission of a crossword and publication, is it too much to ask to have a small team of (volunteer?) beta testers to check the different platforms before going live?
Okay, so no underline. But would it have been so difficult to make those letters lowercase rather than caps?  Or italic rather than roman?  ???

Skimmed the comments so far and, as noted, the PDF version had a mix of upper and lower case letters which led to a quick and fun solve trying to guess the theme answers with a minimum of crosses.  

I don't have the Games App on my iPhone but the website presentation has the candidate clues in all caps with underlines.  That certainly would have added to the challenge.  Condolences to those with no underlines and no hint as to what was going on.  

So it seems a good puzzle spoiled by a ham handed technical delivery.  

So often we PDF'ers miss out on "special characters" in the clues.   Guess that's PARTANDPARCEL of the experience.  

LOL of the day goes to our @Andrzej who said, " . . and SEPTA (which sounds like a sewage company rather than anything else) ."
I managed to solve without understanding the trick and reading the column did not  help.   I‚Äôll take the W  to keep the streak to 1000 alive,  but otherwise this was a meh for me.

Count me among those who finished this puzzle easily but with a perplexed expression on my face.
But The Times gets a lot wrong on the app, not just in regard to puzzles. For example, why can it not remember that I prefer to read the oldest comments first, when the Washington Post and the Guardian have no trouble doing so? A minor point, but it should be simple.

Even the extra examples provided in the constructors‚Äô comments weren‚Äôt properly printed. Was that for consistency? ‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre going to fail our constructors in one place, let‚Äôs fail them everywhere!‚Äù That was the poor decision at the end of this article. At the beginning of the article there was no reflection on having failed the constructors, just a notice telling us the app didn‚Äôt work right. Not only that, but that comment at the top incorrectly identifies what things look like in the pdf. Deb‚Äôs awesome, so I presume this top-to-bottom fail wasn‚Äôt her idea.

Sorry for those who had no help. I had underlines and if I had got SPA correct this would've been my fastest Thursday. Even so, I was beyond delighted with this puzzle.

I'm glad I took a break from the crossword for most of December. I wasn't enjoying myself, but yesterday and today have been delights.
Was it just me who wondered at ‚ÄúSri‚Äù for 47 across ‚ÄúA title of respect?‚Äù Surely this is a typo of ‚ÄúSir‚Äù? Or was it doing something more clever than I was?
To the constructor:  I loved this puzzle.  Sorry the tech glitch is dominating the comments.

Epic fail on the part of the editors.  When the top TEN Reader Picks are all complaints about something that is no fault of the constructors, the editors have screwed up big time.

FWIW, acknowledging the problem in Deb‚Äôs column is no help at all.  How many people read Wordplay BEFORE they try the puzzle?

Had to look up four general knowledge items (UTES, ERICA, KANT, TERESA) in order to get some solid extras but it seems my mind was on the right track for a bunch of the other clues and I was able to solve this one after I understood the theme.
Since the NYTimes makes the app available and charges for it monthly, it seems unfair to have a puzzle without the clues needed to understand it completely when using the app.
Yup, piling on!  Stop having puzzles that don‚Äôt work in app, or come up with different work around (shaded boxes, maybe?) With the volume of submissions, hard to see the need for this.
Worked perfectly fine on my Android phone. Just saying...

No underlining for me, so I spent considerable effort looking for anagrams of the capitalized clues that would explain the second part of the entries. Proud to say that I discovered COLA, SCAMS, and ACRE, (among other words), but couldn‚Äôt make anything of the remaining letters. (DRY BAR COLA was the closest I got.) Finally went to read Deb‚Äôs column and was glad I didn‚Äôt expend any more needless effort looking for anagrams that didn‚Äôt exist. 

I must say that I felt a bit like Alice trying to solve the riddle ‚ÄúHow is a raven like a writing desk?‚Äù only to be eventually told that there is no answer.

Way too hard for me.
Deb, I did check to see if underlined letters spelled a word... saw TROT, for example.
But that got me nowhere!

Give me a rebus any day!

Sorry for all of you who had no underlining. But really sorry for our constructors - such a wonderful puzzle but that's getting largely buried under the technical glitch. 

Anyway - I had the underlines and tumbling to the trick was a huge turning point for me. Just had a great time pondering possibilities for both clues and nice 'oh, of course!' moments for every one of them. Somehow ended up well under my Thursday average. 

Answer history search today led to a couple of VERY unusual puzzles. I'll put those in replies. 

..
My emotional response to this puzzle was sheer irritation.  Too "clever" by half.

No underlines for me on the iPad app. I got MOMANDPOP early on crosses then guessed by following the pattern for the other theme answers. One of my fastest Thursdays. 
I often don‚Äôt get the theme until reading the column.

The underlines don‚Äôt appear in the Wordplay article, either, so we also have to guess at the complete clues they considered, but decided against. I agree with everyone else that there should be a way to show all of the information.
I was proud of myself for solving a puzzle on my iPad without knowing what the heck I was doing. When I read about underlined letters, my pride morphed into fury.

Major disappointment for a Thursday puzzle with the tech glitch in the app.  A simple comment in the Info section to check out the grid online for the underlines would have made this puzzle so much more enjoyable.   Instead, many of us experienced big time  frustration!
If they couldn‚Äôt use bold in the app, couldn‚Äôt they have used a parentheses to indicate the letters? Very frustrating.

I finished the puzzle (on the app, no underlining) and still couldn‚Äôt for the life of me figure out the theme. After reading Wordplay for some enlightenment, I‚Äôm a bit bummed out NYT published an incomplete puzzle for us IPhone users. 

A simple fix would have been to use a mix of lower case and capital letters, instead of all caps and underlining.
Why wasn‚Äôt the lack of underlining mentioned in the notes under the ‚Äúi‚Äù icon on the app? That‚Äôs usually where the editors let us know the app is lacking.
Referring to a fundamental flaw that utterly ruins the puzzle and makes it unsolvable for a large portion of your audience as ‚Äúadministration‚Äù is simply pathetic.

It‚Äôs sincerely unacceptable for a puzzle to be published in a state that it isn‚Äôt functional for all subscribers, especially when subscription prices are rising. 

But even worse than that, it‚Äôs an insult to Chase and Christina who put so much time into what is otherwise an excellent puzzle. One of my goals for the year is to submit a puzzle I‚Äôve been workshopping with a friend, but technical issues like this make me question if it‚Äôs worth it. We‚Äôve spent several hours brainstorming themes and how to implement and clue them, and it‚Äôs frustrating to now have to consider technical limitations like this. 

Hopefully the rest of the years publications will put me in a more productive mood.

As an iPad user guessed hiTANDRUN from the crosses first. Then guessed the others.  Had to dredge up CUt.  Not one to complain, but REALLY?  So many ways to represent the special attention to be paid to certain letters.  Good thing the expressions were easy to guess.

I don‚Äôt check out the column until I‚Äôm done or feel hopelessly stuck. I bet I‚Äôm not alone in that. A technical note in the column does me *zero good*. 

The app has a section for instructions, clues, titles etc. Why-oh-why would you not put the info about the underlined letters in the place the people affected by the technical issue will actually see it! The app has this functionality!

I'm an Android user, the puzzle worked fine for me, but I'm mad on behalf of the Apple users. It's ridiculous to have an app with one job and then publish a puzzle that just doesn't work for a huge chunk of users. And you knew it would be a problem, judging by the Wordplay column, and you pushed it anyway. Insane decision that must have been made by people who think crosswords are mostly done in print.

Fury? No. Outrage? No. Anger? No. Irritation? No. Annoyance? Maybe, if I hadn‚Äôt solved it quickly without reference to the theme. Let‚Äôs say I‚Äôm mildly displeased that I had no warning I was missing the complete puzzle when solving. Surely a blinking round ‚ÄúI‚Äù could have been used as in puzzles past.

Though I agree with all the i-people complaining about how this puzzle was not formatted in a way that allowed us to enjoy the theme, I want to observe that having the underlined letters would have made a very easy Thursday puzzle even easier. So if you‚Äôre going to have a dumb technical error, doing it today is better than on a day with more fiendish clues. Also, I liked the puzzle, but without the modest trick, it would have felt much more like a Wednesday.

Well I‚Äôm glad I‚Äôm not losing my mind, because I came here to get clued in on what the themed clues had to do with the answers. Glad they were fairly easy sayings to figure out. Woulda hated to lose my streak on a glitch.
Let me get this straight, I pay extra to enjoy the puzzle on my iphone and it doesn‚Äôt work.  I‚Äôd like my money back.
Interrupting my solve to point out a rare error. The ODDS against snake-eyes are 35:1. The probability of snake-eyes is 1/36.

While I understand (and relate to) the outpouring of frustration re: underlining, it's a little sad that any comment or critique of the puzzle gets lost so easily.

Technical issues aside, I found this to be a delightful and breezy Thursday puzzle, with some excellent cluing ("Go from 0 to 60, say" for COUNT was my personal favorite). I didn't encounter any true Naticks, learned a few pieces of trivia (RABAT has a royal palace!) and had fun deducing the theme once I caught the COLA in Carol Brady's name.

Overall, a very fun and fairly easy Thursday that seems to have been done a great disservice by technical issues.
Amazing that you would simply not care about the app users‚Äô experience

Easy enough for a Thursday, even without the underlined letters (solving on an iPad). I know this makes me sound like a crabby old lady (which I am) but this isn‚Äôt the first time we‚Äôve had a technical quirk like this and while it‚Äôs a small thing to deal with given the lousy state of our world today, the fact is that I‚Äôm paying for this app, dammit, and it ought to work right every time. If the puzzle doesn‚Äôt work across all platforms correctly, you shouldn‚Äôt run it, period. But why didn‚Äôt it work? Underlining is easy! And if that were a challenge, why not capitalize them instead (CarOL brAdy)? It just ends up feeling like no effort was put in to give the app customers a quality product. Come on guys, you‚Äôre the New York Times! You should be setting the standard here, not phoning it in.

Well, glitch happens, but, IMO, it would be good form for the Times to put out an apology to the solvers who were deprived of the full pleasure of experiencing this terrific theme, and to the constructors, whose hard-made puzzle brought frustration rather than delight to many.

@Deb Amlen

I always enjoy your columns! I'm with you about the emotional boost from those AHA moments while solving - and I often smile when I read similarities in your solving experience to mine. (Today it was PAGES. So great!!)

I would like to make a correction to a descriptor in today's Tricky Clues, though. I do it with some reticence given that you are also having to be the interlocutor for all the technology grief being expressed! But I feel it's an important enough distinction to persevere...

For 27D, you say that ATTA is "used to make East Asian flatbreads such as roti, chapati and paratha."  Atta is indeed used to make those delicious items, but the region from which they originate is *South* Asia, the cuisine which we broadly call Indian here in the States. Roti is also made in parts of Southeast Asia, but chapati and paratha do not have the same culinary reach - and certainly do not extend to East Asian menus!
